articles.headline: Behind the Obama-Harris Friendship: A Key Endorsement and a Kindred Spirit
articles.snippet: Kamala Harris’s decision to support Barack Obama in a 2008 primary race dominated by Hillary Clinton was a political risk. It paid off, and the former president never forgot it.
articles.abstract: Kamala Harris’s decision to support Barack Obama in a 2008 primary race dominated by Hillary Clinton was a political risk. It paid off, and the former president never forgot it.
articles.lead_paragraph: On New Year’s Eve in 2007, Kamala Harris, then the district attorney of San Francisco, prepared to spend the holiday more than a thousand miles away from her native California. She had flown to Iowa for the first time, touching down in Des Moines during one of the wettest winters on record.

articles.headline: 25 Years Ago, a Gay Student Sought Support. His School Turned to Tim Walz.
articles.snippet: One student’s turbulent coming-out journey in the 1990s put Mr. Walz, then a football coach, at the center of gay rights in a Minnesota high school.
articles.abstract: One student’s turbulent coming-out journey in the 1990s put Mr. Walz, then a football coach, at the center of gay rights in a Minnesota high school.
articles.lead_paragraph: Taunts and threats escalated as rumors about Jacob Reitan’s sexual orientation swirled around his southern Minnesota high school during his senior year in 1999.

articles.headline: Biden Approved Secret Nuclear Strategy Refocusing on Chinese Threat
articles.snippet: In a classified document approved in March, the president ordered U.S. forces to prepare for possible coordinated nuclear confrontations with Russia, China and North Korea.
articles.abstract: In a classified document approved in March, the president ordered U.S. forces to prepare for possible coordinated nuclear confrontations with Russia, China and North Korea.
articles.lead_paragraph: President Biden approved in March a highly classified nuclear strategic plan for the United States that, for the first time, reorients America’s deterrent strategy to focus on China’s rapid expansion in its nuclear arsenal.

articles.headline: China’s ‘Road Trip Auntie’ Is Ready for a New Milestone: Divorce
articles.snippet: Su Min became an internet sensation for leaving behind an abusive husband to drive across China alone. Now she’s ending the marriage, but there will be a price.
articles.abstract: Su Min became an internet sensation for leaving behind an abusive husband to drive across China alone. Now she’s ending the marriage, but there will be a price.
articles.lead_paragraph: In the four years since she began driving solo across China, leaving behind an abusive marriage and longstanding expectations about women’s duties at home, Su Min, 60, has become an internet sensation known as the “road-trip auntie.”
articles.byline: By Vivian Wang and Joy Dong

articles.headline: They Spouted Hate Online. Then They Were Arrested.
articles.snippet: As hundreds of people appear in court for their role in recent anti-immigrant riots in Britain, several are accused of fueling disorder through online posts, raising questions about the limits of free speech.
articles.abstract: As hundreds of people appear in court for their role in recent anti-immigrant riots in Britain, several are accused of fueling disorder through online posts, raising questions about the limits of free speech.
articles.lead_paragraph: A 53-year-old woman from northwest England was jailed for 15 months after posting on Facebook that a mosque should be blown up “with the adults inside.” A 45-year-old man was sentenced to 20 months for goading his online followers to torch a hotel that houses refugees. A 55-year-old woman was questioned by the police for a viral post that wrongly identified the suspect in a deadly knife attack at a children’s dance class.

articles.headline: She Survived the Maui Wildfires. She Couldn’t Survive the Year After.
articles.snippet: Edralina Diezon was working as a janitor and sending money to her family in the Philippines when wildfires destroyed everything she had. The road to rebuilding her life proved to be perilous.
articles.abstract: Edralina Diezon was working as a janitor and sending money to her family in the Philippines when wildfires destroyed everything she had. The road to rebuilding her life proved to be perilous.
articles.lead_paragraph: As a whirlwind of flames nearly encircled the Lahaina Gateway shopping center on Aug. 8, 2023, Edralina Diezon hid in a storage room, surrounded by mops, buckets and brooms. Terrified, Ms. Diezon, who worked 80 hours a week as a janitor, did not leave for two days and two nights. When she finally emerged, starving and disoriented, the neighborhood where she lived was gone.

articles.headline: The Small-Town Nebraska Tim Walz Put Behind Him, but Never Fully Left
articles.snippet: A political persona forged on the prairie: self-assured but rarely self-serious; puckish when possible, stoic when necessary.
articles.abstract: A political persona forged on the prairie: self-assured but rarely self-serious; puckish when possible, stoic when necessary.
articles.lead_paragraph: Tim Walz was 14 or so, trouble-seeking with his cousins across a shaggy patch of family land where they liked to shoot air guns at birds.
articles.byline: By Matt Flegenheimer and Kenny Holston

articles.headline: Consumers Are Still Bargain Shopping, Macy’s and Target Reports Show
articles.snippet: Department store chains have struggled as Americans, squeezed by budget constraints, spend less time and money at their stores.
articles.abstract: Department store chains have struggled as Americans, squeezed by budget constraints, spend less time and money at their stores.
articles.lead_paragraph: As U.S. consumers navigate an economy still rocked by high inflation, they are guided by tight wallets and cheaper goods, a trend that’s hitting department store chains like Macy’s harder than discount retailers like Target and T.J. Maxx.
articles.byline: By Jordyn Holman and Danielle Kaye

articles.headline: U.S. Added 818,000 Fewer Jobs Than Reported Earlier
articles.snippet: The Labor Department issued revised figures for the 12 months through March that point to greater economic fragility.
articles.abstract: The Labor Department issued revised figures for the 12 months through March that point to greater economic fragility.
articles.lead_paragraph: The U.S. economy added far fewer jobs in 2023 and early 2024 than previously reported, a sign that cracks in the labor market are more severe — and began forming earlier — than initially believed.

articles.headline: The Year of the A.I. Election That Wasn’t
articles.snippet: More than 30 tech companies have pitched A.I. tools to political campaigns for November’s election. The campaigns have been wary.
articles.abstract: More than 30 tech companies have pitched A.I. tools to political campaigns for November’s election. The campaigns have been wary.
articles.lead_paragraph: Matthew Diemer, a Democrat running for election in Ohio’s Seventh Congressional District, was approached by the artificial intelligence company Civox in January with a pitch: A.I.-backed voice technology that could make tens of thousands of personalized phone calls to voters using Mr. Diemer’s talking points and sense of humor.
